title: ChatGPT for Business Updates

rawLines.text: [Music]
Hey everybody, thanks for joining today.
I'm Nate and I lead the chat for chatbt
for business product team. Now today's
live stream is all about how we help
bring your organization's unique work
context directly into chatbt. And so way
that we do that is we enable you to
connect your internal knowledge sources
to chatpt uh so that you can find the
most relevant information at the right
moment. We also respect all of the
existing user permissions inside of your
organization and we keep uh your data
private and secure within the team and
enterprise workspaces. So there are two
experiences that we're going to walk
through to show how we bring this
context in. The first is connectors to
your internal data uh to power deep
research and also just everyday queries
with chatbt. And the second is record
mode where we can capture and help you
make better use of all the information
that is spoken in meetings but isn't
necessarily written down. And so I can
personally attest to the fact and the
power about these products. We've been
using these every single day within our
teams as we're dog fooding. It is just
amazing to see how we can take the
breadth of information that we have at
OpenAI and that we're creating every
day, be able to synthesize that down
with really targeted queries and then be
able to use that for actionable insights
that drive our product work forward. So
we've been really excited to play with
it. We're excited to show to you all. Um
so joining me is several members of our
product and our research team. Uh, so we
have Neil, Priy, and Dibbo. So, they're
going to take you through the demos
here. So, I'll pass it over to Neil.
Sure. Thanks, Nate. I'm excited to show
you all how we're using connectors to
accelerate our own work here at OpenAI.
Now, we can't show you our own internal
data, but we can show you how connectors
work on a fictitious company we've
created called AGI Corp. I think I would
like to work at a company like that. I
hear it's pretty good. Um, so AGIC Corp
a few months ago launched one of my
favorite fictitious products, animal
GPT. It's a new family of models that
translates animal noises to human text.
What animals are we working on? I think
we have we've launched bark to text and
on the road map is uh meowed text coming
up, but we're right now in the middle of
Q3 planning and kicking it off. So as a
team together, we're going to use our
connectors and all of PT to help us kick
off that whole planning cycle. uh we'll
start off by using deep research and
connectors to help us understand a
little bit more about some of the
upcoming partnerships and launches we
might have going on. So I'll go ahead
and open chatbt and hover over deep
research. Now if you remember deep
research launched in February of this
year and is a new agentic capability in
chatbt that allows you to extensively
search and analyze the web. Now, one of
the big pieces of feedback that we got
from users is that they wanted to not
only deep research over the public web,
but over all of their private sources.
And so, when you click on Deep Research
Now, you're going to see a new sources
drop down. And opening that, you'll see
that Deep Research Now not only connects
to the web, but to all of your favorite
apps, everything from GitHub to
Gmail. I'm going to go through and
toggle on a few that I'm particularly
excited about. For this next query, I'll
do HubSpot and then Outlook, SharePoint,
and
Teams. And what I want to ask Chat GBT
is a little bit more about some of the
potential distribution partnerships we
can lean into for Bark to Text and
Animal GPT. So, I'm asking the model,
hey, we're doing Q3 planning for Animal
GPT and we're excited about potential
distribution partnerships. Can you take
a look at HubSpot and tell me what open
deals are most likely to close that
overlap with our company strategy? and
I'm going to have it cross-reference
those with any discussions and kickoffs
that we have in SharePoint, Teams, and
Outlook. So, I'll go ahead and kick off
that query, and Deep Research will go
ahead and ask me some contextual an uh
questions specific to the applications
we have right now. So, it's asking me
about the company strategy. I'll
say AGI Corp. wants to advance
AGI. Um, but focus, it is a good one. uh
focus on deals with high revenue
potential and high
likelyhood to close in Q3.
Um make sure to cross reference across
all the Microsoft
apps. And with that, deep research is
going to go ahead and kick off and it's
going to spend the next five or 10
minutes extensively searching all the
different apps that I've pointed it
towards. Um, now the really awesome
thing is that a query like this would
have otherwise taken me or my team hours
or even days to comb through HubSpot,
Teams, chat, CRM, messaging. And
instead, Deep Research is going to go
ahead and do that in just a couple
minutes. Yeah. And I think there's
something really powerful about being
able to extend our team's capabilities
as well. So, you know, things like CRM
data are likely data sources that Neil
and other product members may not be as
familiar with. And now you're able to
get answers from that really quickly.
Absolutely. And it's not just CRM. Uh I
use this feature all the time to search
GitHub. I'm sure our engineers think uh
thank it for not uh letting me bother
them every day. Um cool. Well, deep
research uh takes a couple minutes to to
get started. So in the meantime, I'll
hand it over to Priy and Dibbo to show
us what else we can do. Awesome. Thanks,
Neil. So, while deep research is going
on, um, as Neil said, it's great for
really comprehensive reports around a
specific topic, but a lot of times you
just want to quickly go back and forth
in the context of your everyday work.
Um, so we're going to show you, you
know, how you can augment that with
bringing in additional knowledge to to
really streamline the work you do in
chat GPT itself. So, I'm going to open
up a new window here while deep research
is going on, and we're going to use this
to kind of get up to speed on some of
the things going on at the company,
triage a bunch of documents and data
across our file storage systems that we
use here at AGI Corp, and then pull
together a synthesis of what we should
be working on. Um, sounds like we have a
lot of exciting work with Bark Detect
and Meow Detect coming. Um, so let's
start kind of going broad. Um, like I
said, we're new here, so we just want to
get up to speed. So, I'm going to ask
something
like, "Chachi BT, get me up to speed on
our Q2 marketing and
product strategy." Um, and I'm also
curious about revenue. So, I'll say what
features drove the most revenue in Q2.
So, there are a few ways to invoke a
search. uh we've postrained the model to
be good at understanding when the user's
uh question requires internal knowledge.
So in those cases it will try to
automatically trigger that like it's
doing here. But if you just want more
direct access um you we've also built a
new tool into the composer that you can
use to manually toggle on sources that
you want uh chat GBT to search across.
So you can see that in just a few
seconds PRI got a pretty in-depth
summary of uh our Q2 uh plans. Um, do
you want to talk about some of the
sources that the model's showing here?
Yeah, like D.A. said, I mean, the great
thing here is that not only do we get a
really clear summary within a couple
seconds, but each part of the model's
response is actually showing us, um,
what sources it's pulling from. So, we
can verify the information, um, we can
dig deeper. And then we actually have a
source tab here. So, if you want to
engage individually with certain
documents, I can ask it to deep dive um,
on individual documents if I want to
continue my research there. Um, all of
these sources, like Nate said at the
beginning, are permission aware and
enforced. So, I'm only able to see the
documents that I have access to. Here,
we're signed into my account. So, I work
very closely with our board team here at
AJ Corp., so we can see that I have
access, and it's pulling up some of the
board decks, but actually looks like
Debo doesn't. So, don't look too
closely. I mean, it's fine. They don't
give it to Neil and I either. No, keep
us in the dark. Okay. So coming back to
the summary here as um Neil was
mentioning it does look like Bart to tax
v2 is doing pretty well. So maybe let's
see if we have any information on
engagement. It looks like retention was
pretty good but let's see if we can get
up to speed here. So let me ask Chachi
to generate a
time series plot of daily active users
for Bark to text
V2. Um, and it looks like Chetch is
automatically launching into data
analytics mode. So, I use this feature a
ton and normally the way I would do it
is I would have to update upload um,
spreadsheets that first kind of go into
Google Drive and find where the data is
located, then manually upload it here.
Here, the great thing is it already has
context on my enterprise knowledge. So,
it's able to automatically draw in that
data. So, I can get straight to work.
Um, so here within a second I was able
to look up, you know, a pretty generic
query on what DAO looks like for Bart to
text V2. Yeah, it looks like we're
crushing it. We love to see that.
Probably it's time for me to text. Um,
and to help us with that, I actually
think um, our user research team was
doing a bunch of user interviews. Um,
let's see if we can find anything
relevant there.
So let me ask chatbt find user
interviews from
Dropbox from recent pet
owners. There we go. And now u as you
can see um I'm kind of using natural
language to filter down the query a
little bit. Um I have a few different um
parameters here and Dropbox was
highlighted because um I'm you know it's
telling the model that um I should
prioritize data from there. So we've
built a little bit of a UI to let you
know that the model is really
prioritizing that source as
well. So based on the specific query
parameters, I asked it for recency, I
asked it from Dropbox, and I asked it
from pet owners because as Neil was
looking at, we have a ton of
stakeholders ranging from vet clinics to
to different kind of partnerships. So, I
just wanted to look at pet owner
specifically as we think about meat text
v2. Um, and we have a few different user
interviews here. So, normally we'd kind
of go through and read all of these,
which would take a bunch of time to
synthesize. Um, as a PM, I spent a ton
of my week doing that. U, but let's see
if we can kind of bootstrap that and ask
chat to help synthesize for us. Let me
ask
synthesis of these interviews.
to pull
top pain points and ops ranked by return
on investment. And then I want this to
be immediately actionable. So let me say
something like turn this into a Q3 plan
and
generate a doc. And it's the last thing.
A lot of times when you're doing your
work, it's not it's most useful if it's
actually in the language and the way
that you actually work within your
company. So, I'll ask it to cross
reference our template um to format it
in the right way, too. Let me ask. And
this is our Q3 planning template. Yes.
Look up
our our
planning template doc and follow that.
So behind the scenes once the model's
decided that it needs to use internal
knowledge to answer uh the user's
question um it's going to go ahead and
rewrite uh it into one or more
contextualized queries um with different
attributes like um how recent it needs
the results to be or um what sources it
wants to filter down to uh for the
search. And then our search backend can
operate on these queries and um return
the most relevant results that the user
already has permissions to view. Um and
then given these results, the model can
then decide to go back and ask follow-up
questions or u uh dig into some of these
files by opening them, use some other
tool, um or just answer right away.
Yeah. And it actually looks like in the
last couple minutes I lost access to the
planning template. I guess some things
changed around here, but that kind of
shows you how, you know, permissions are
always respected here. Um, and it's
really up todate and that's really
important to how we built the system.
So, within a couple seconds, we were
able to go through um, and get a
prioritized list of what we should be
building, some core metrics that we look
at, um, as well as some of the the core
work streams here. So, it looks like
Neil, you're going to be working on
contextual intelligence, um, and I'll be
working on our pet memory layer, but we
have a busy Q3 ahead of us. So, That was
just kind of an endto-end flow on how
bringing in some of your enterprise
knowledge will really augment the work
you do in chat GBT and can help you
centralize a little bit more. So we're
excited to start rolling this out today
across file storage systems where um
enterprises have a large portion of
their enterprise knowledge. So um Google
Drive as well as SharePoint, Dropbox um
and Box in beta. Um this is rolling out
for Teams, enterprise and edu. And just
as a reminder, by default, we don't
train on any data um across teams, EDU,
and enterprise. Um as well as and that
includes any connected data as well. So
this is still early days for connectors.
Um while connectors remains in beta,
we're excited to see how you use this
with your work and we are committed to
continuous improvement and testing.
Great. Thank you guys. Now, I want to
invite another one of our PMs uh over to
uh to sit with us who's going to talk
through the next feature of record mode.
So, Sandra is going to be joining us.
And I can assure you there is nobody who
is more excited for me out to text than
she is.
Thanks, Nate. That's right. I'd love to
talk to my kittens. Um all right. So,
having the ability to get answers across
all your documents and data sources is a
huge win. Um, but we also know that
that's just really half the story,
right? A lot of the important decisions
and context from our work actually
happens in the conversations that we
have with our teammates. Absolutely. And
so that's why we're introducing chatbt
record mode. It's a way for us to help
make sure that your notes are complete,
that they're not scattered. You're also
not having to um multitask during a
meeting where you're really trying to
engage and you're having to take notes
at the same time.
So, with record mode, what we're
introducing is on our Mac OS desktop
app, you will see a uh circle icon uh
button next to all of the other voice
options. And with just clicking on this
button, you will get a recording. So,
right now, Chat GPT is recording all of
our audio. And on the back end, it's
transcribing that audio, and it's going
to generate a really useful summary for
me afterwards. So, for now, we're not
going to record this session. So, I'm
going to go ahead and just close this
out. Um but let's look at you know AGI
Corp's Q3 pounce plan. Um so the team
last week was doing a uh brainstorming
session around personality aware
translation and they were really talking
through like the different options that
they had and they recorded that session.
So you can see that there is a
structured meeting output here. And if
you navigate down the page, what you'll
see is that there are key points, action
items, and most importantly, they're
always citing the transcript. So if I'm
if I have more questions about, hey, the
energy trait, that's where we're going
to focus our personality translation on,
what what was spoken about that, like
what should I know about that, it's
going to go highlight that section
exactly in the transcript, so you always
have that full full context. These time
stamps are awesome. Makes it really easy
to figure out where exactly the things
were said. Like we said, we use this
every single day inside of the the
teams. And it's uh being able to to kind
of go from the summary to the transcript
is really really powerful. So if I were
in a meeting and I were going to share
something back with Sandre and she
didn't have full context, she's able to
get the the kind of TLDDR on the
summary, but then also go to the
individual details when she needs to.
Yep. Exactly. Um the great thing too is
let's say like we fast forward a couple
of weeks and I'm trying to remember what
actually happened in that meeting,
right? And this happens all the time.
things move fast at OpenAI and so I
imagine they move fast at AGI Corp as
well. Um, and let's say I was saying,
hey, like what were the technical
limitations that we discussed at our Q3
planning, I can go ahead and send that
note to chat GPT. ChatGpt is going to
scan across all of the data sources,
again, docs, data sources, but also our
transcripts. They're included in that
overall corpus as well. And so you can
see, hey, you know, what we flagged was
the latency issues, the GPU resource
constraints. Um, and with it you have
all of these embedded links directly
into the transcript. So again, you can
have that full
context. And then from here, what's
really great is I might ask, okay, um,
help me draft a leadership uh, draft a
leadership
update on our
Q3 Q3 road map. We definitely don't look
for an out. There's no way. Um yeah, so
like just like that, something that
would have taken me uh a lot of pinging
folks, trying to get the full context of
the meeting, those other teammates,
trying to remember what happened in the
meeting, all of that's actually captured
and chat GPT becomes your second memory,
right? And so with that, um I'm able to
both recall, understand clarity on what
the decisions were made and then
immediately turn that out into a
leadership update that normally would
have taken me a bunch of time.
Um so with that I would love to Neil
show us what what Deep Research is up
to. Yeah absolutely. Thanks Sandra.
Cool. Uh so as you remember uh earlier
we kicked off a deep research query that
was looking at all of the different
partnership and distribution deals we
might be able to do with animal GBT as
we go into Q3. Uh so it looks like now
if we come back to chatbt deep research
has actually spent 9 minutes doing a
really comprehensive search of all these
different applications and it's pulled
together what seems to be a really
comprehensive report on all of our
distribution partnerships. So you can
see in chatbt the models put together
some really great summary insights some
comp Q3 opportunities um in a really
good table too. So, it shows us
opportunities, deal stage, close dates,
revenue, strategic fit, cross reference,
discussion. And the awesome thing, too,
is that it's pulling all the different
citations from all the different sources
that we've hooked it up to. You can see
HubSpot, Teams, SharePoint, and Outlook
all put together here. Again, this is
the kind of work that would have taken
me, you know, hours to do, and we got it
all done in minutes.
Now, we just showed a small set of
connectors just now with Deep Research,
but the amazing thing is that we've
added a whole new set of connectors that
are launching today with Deep Research.
Just to go down the laundry list so we
all see them together, we've got Box,
Dropbox, GitHub, Gmail, Calendar, Google
Drive, HubSpot, Linear Out, Calendar,
Out, SharePoint, Teams. What's that
whisker DB? You know, that is not a
typical first-party connector. That is a
custom connector powered by MCP or model
context protocol that I've loaded up
into chatbt. Uh we're excited to
announce that chatbt is now supporting
MCP custom connectors building on the
work that we've done with the responses
API over the past month. What this means
is that if you're an admin for an
enterprise or team workspace, you can
connect a custom MCP connector and
publish it to your organization. This is
really awesome if you have, you know,
custom databases like Whisker DB that
you want to expose to all of your users.
And if you're a prouser, you can also
connect custom sources and publish it to
your own personal
chatbt. Not only that, but we're also
partnering a lot more with the
ecosystem. In fact, the HubSpot
connector that we just demoed wasn't
built by us. It was built by the HubSpot
developer team, and it's the first MCP
custom connector that we've published
directly in our registry.
Yeah, that's great. So, there's one more
thing that I want to chat with you all
about before we break today. So, to
support the diverse way that all of you,
all of our customers use ChatBT, we're
making our pricing much more flexible.
So tangibly what this means is that
we're adding credits to all of our
existing uh workspaces across uh
enterprise and team. And so your users
now will get full access with their
existing plans to all of our most uh
intelligent and advanced model features
and new models that we're rolling out.
So this is going out to enterprise today
and we'll be launching to team in the
next couple of weeks. So now I want to
recap all the different pieces that
we've talked about today and kind of
bring it back together. So what we
showed you is how chat GPT is able to
take your company's context and make it

accessible across your entire employee
base, leveraging connectors and record

cleanText:
[Music]
Hey everybody, thanks for joining today.
I'm Nate, and I lead the chat for ChatGPT for Business product team.
Now, today's live stream is all about how we help bring your organization's unique work context directly into ChatGPT.
And so, the way that we do that is we enable you to connect your internal knowledge sources to ChatGPT, uh, so that you can find the most relevant information at the right moment.
We also respect all of the existing user permissions inside of your organization, and we keep, uh, your data private and secure within the team and enterprise workspaces.
So, there are two experiences that we're going to walk through to show how we bring this context in.
The first is connectors to your internal data, uh, to power deep research and also just everyday queries with ChatGPT.
And the second is record mode, where we can capture and help you make better use of all the information that is spoken in meetings but isn't necessarily written down.
And so, I can personally attest to the fact and the power about these products.
We've been using these every single day within our teams as we're dogfooding.
It is just amazing to see how we can take the breadth of information that we have at OpenAI and that we're creating every day, be able to synthesize that down with really targeted queries and then be able to use that for actionable insights that drive our product work forward.
So, we've been really excited to play with it.
We're excited to show to you all.
Um, so joining me is several members of our product and our research team.
Uh, so we have Neel, Preeti, and Dibya.
So, they're going to take you through the demos here.
So, I'll pass it over to Neel.
Sure.
Thanks, Nate.
I'm excited to show you all how we're using connectors to accelerate our own work here at OpenAI.
Now, we can't show you our own internal data, but we can show you how connectors work on a fictitious company we've created called AGI Corp.
I think I would like to work at a company like that.
I hear it's pretty good.
Um, so AGIC Corp a few months ago launched one of my favorite fictitious products, animal GPT.
It's a new family of models that translates animal noises to human text.
What animals are we working on?
I think we have, we've launched bark to text, and on the road map is, uh, meowed text coming up, but we're right now in the middle of Q3 planning and kicking it off.
So as a team together, we're going to use our connectors and all of ChatGPT to help us kick off that whole planning cycle.
Uh, we'll start off by using deep research and connectors to help us understand a little bit more about some of the upcoming partnerships and launches we might have going on.
So I'll go ahead and open ChatGPT and hover over deep research.
Now, if you remember, deep research launched in February of this year and is a new agentic capability in ChatGPT that allows you to extensively search and analyze the web.
Now, one of the big pieces of feedback that we got from users is that they wanted to not only deep research over the public web, but over all of their private sources.
And so, when you click on Deep Research Now, you're going to see a new sources drop down.
And opening that, you'll see that Deep Research Now not only connects to the web, but to all of your favorite apps, everything from GitHub to Gmail.
I'm going to go through and toggle on a few that I'm particularly excited about.
For this next query, I'll do HubSpot and then Outlook, SharePoint, and Teams.
And what I want to ask ChatGPT is a little bit more about some of the potential distribution partnerships we can lean into for Bark to Text and Animal GPT.
So, I'm asking the model, hey, we're doing Q3 planning for Animal GPT, and we're excited about potential distribution partnerships.
Can you take a look at HubSpot and tell me what open deals are most likely to close that overlap with our company strategy?
And I'm going to have it cross-reference those with any discussions and kickoffs that we have in SharePoint, Teams, and Outlook.
So, I'll go ahead and kick off that query, and Deep Research will go ahead and ask me some contextual, an, uh, questions specific to the applications we have right now.
So, it's asking me about the company strategy.
I'll say AGI Corp. wants to advance AGI.
Um, but focus, it is a good one.
Uh, focus on deals with high revenue potential and high likelyhood to close in Q3.
Um, make sure to cross reference across all the Microsoft apps.
And with that, deep research is going to go ahead and kick off, and it's going to spend the next five or 10 minutes extensively searching all the different apps that I've pointed it towards.
Um, now the really awesome thing is that a query like this would have otherwise taken me or my team hours or even days to comb through HubSpot, Teams, chat, CRM, messaging.
And instead, Deep Research is going to go ahead and do that in just a couple minutes.
Yeah.
And I think there's something really powerful about being able to extend our team's capabilities as well.
So, you know, things like CRM data are likely data sources that Neel and other product members may not be as familiar with.
And now you're able to get answers from that really quickly.
Absolutely.
And it's not just CRM.
Uh, I use this feature all the time to search GitHub.
I'm sure our engineers think, uh, thank it for not, uh, letting me bother them every day.
Um, cool.
Well, deep research, uh, takes a couple minutes to get started.
So in the meantime, I'll hand it over to Preeti and Dibya to show us what else we can do.
Awesome.
Thanks, Neil.
So, while deep research is going on, um, as Neil said, it's great for really comprehensive reports around a specific topic, but a lot of times you just want to quickly go back and forth in the context of your everyday work.
Um, so we're going to show you, you know, how you can augment that with bringing in additional knowledge to, to really streamline the work you do in ChatGPT itself.
So, I'm going to open up a new window here while deep research is going on, and we're going to use this to kind of get up to speed on some of the things going on at the company, triage a bunch of documents and data across our file storage systems that we use here at AGI Corp, and then pull together a synthesis of what we should be working on.
Um, sounds like we have a lot of exciting work with Bark Detect and Meow Detect coming.
Um, so let's start kind of going broad.
Um, like I said, we're new here, so we just want to get up to speed.
So, I'm going to ask something like, "ChatGPT, get me up to speed on our Q2 marketing and product strategy."
Um, and I'm also curious about revenue.
So, I'll say what features drove the most revenue in Q2.
So, there are a few ways to invoke a search.
Uh, we've postrained the model to be good at understanding when the user's, uh, question requires internal knowledge.
So in those cases it will try to automatically trigger that like it's doing here.
But if you just want more direct access, um, you, we've also built a new tool into the composer that you can use to manually toggle on sources that you want, uh, ChatGPT to search across.
So you can see that in just a few seconds, Preeti got a pretty in-depth summary of, uh, our Q2, uh, plans.
Um, do you want to talk about some of the sources that the model's showing here?
Yeah, like Dibya said, I mean, the great thing here is that not only do we get a really clear summary within a couple seconds, but each part of the model's response is actually showing us, um, what sources it's pulling from.
So, we can verify the information, um, we can dig deeper.
And then we actually have a source tab here.
So, if you want to engage individually with certain documents, I can ask it to deep dive, um, on individual documents if I want to continue my research there.
Um, all of these sources, like Nate said at the beginning, are permission aware and enforced.
